pull_request.title: Add missing custom-lib directory [HZ-3591]
pull_request.body:
After removal of the hazelcast 3 connector it turned out that `custom-lib` directory is missing in the distribution archives

Fixes https://hazelcast.atlassian.net/browse/HZ-3591

EE PR: Ihttps://github.com/hazelcast/hazelcast-enterprise/pull/6707

Breaking changes (list specific methods/types/messages):
* API
* client protocol format
* serialized form
* snapshot format

issue.title: ICache method setExpiryPolicy with CreatedExpiryPolicy set max duration independently on passed value [HZ-3264]

labels.name: Source: Internal
labels.description: PR or issue was opened by an employee

issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
ICache method `setExpiryPolicy` suppose to set a new expiry policy for the given key in the cache. However it seems it's currently ignored (tried with `CreatedExpiryPolicy`) and once it's called the given entry is never removed from the cache (instead of using the new policy).

**Expected behavior**
New policy should be applied for the entry with given key in the cache.

**To Reproduce**

Use `cache.setExpiryPolicy` as following:
```
ICache<String, String> cache = client.getCacheManager().getCache("hz/myCache");
cache.put("k", "v", new CreatedExpiryPolicy(new Duration(TimeUnit.MILLISECONDS, 5000)));
cache.setExpiryPolicy("k", new CreatedExpiryPolicy(new Duration(TimeUnit.MILLISECONDS, 6000)));
```
and check that entry "k" is never removed from the cache. If the `cache.setExpiryPolicy()` is not called then entry expires in 5 seconds.

issue.title: ICache method setExpiryPolicy with CreatedExpiryPolicy set max duration independently on passed value [HZ-3264]

labels.name: Source: Internal
labels.description: PR or issue was opened by an employee

issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
ICache method `setExpiryPolicy` suppose to set a new expiry policy for the given key in the cache. However it seems it's currently ignored (tried with `CreatedExpiryPolicy`) and once it's called the given entry is never removed from the cache (instead of using the new policy).

**Expected behavior**
New policy should be applied for the entry with given key in the cache.

**To Reproduce**

Use `cache.setExpiryPolicy` as following:
```
ICache<String, String> cache = client.getCacheManager().getCache("hz/myCache");
cache.put("k", "v", new CreatedExpiryPolicy(new Duration(TimeUnit.MILLISECONDS, 5000)));
cache.setExpiryPolicy("k", new CreatedExpiryPolicy(new Duration(TimeUnit.MILLISECONDS, 6000)));
```
and check that entry "k" is never removed from the cache. If the `cache.setExpiryPolicy()` is not called then entry expires in 5 seconds.

comment.body:
Investigation of this issue and testing has determined that the functionality in the code adheres to the contract of the ICache interface for method setExpiryPolicy.

See note on JavaDoc :

* Note: New time-to-live duration is calculated using newly added entry policy's getExpiryForUpdate method
 * immediately after this operation succeeds.
The result is that the CacheRecord:expiryTime will get set to a value determined with the use of the expiryForUpdate value provided in the expiry policy. CreatedExpiryPolicy returns a null for expiryForUpdate, leading to a -1 expiry on the record - which means we will never expire the record.

With the test case provided you have two options to achieve the result you expected:

(1) invoke setExpiryPolicy for the cache entry with a policy such as HazelcastExpiryPolicy which accepts createDurationAmount, accessDurationAmount, updateDurationAmount-> supply updateDurationAmount as 6000 ms.
(2) re-invoke the original put with the new CreatedExpiryPolicy.

Closing with this context - thanks for raising this issue!

issue.title: ICache method setExpiryPolicy with CreatedExpiryPolicy set max duration independently on passed value [HZ-3264]

labels.name: Source: Internal
labels.description: PR or issue was opened by an employee

issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
ICache method `setExpiryPolicy` suppose to set a new expiry policy for the given key in the cache. However it seems it's currently ignored (tried with `CreatedExpiryPolicy`) and once it's called the given entry is never removed from the cache (instead of using the new policy).

**Expected behavior**
New policy should be applied for the entry with given key in the cache.

**To Reproduce**

Use `cache.setExpiryPolicy` as following:
```
ICache<String, String> cache = client.getCacheManager().getCache("hz/myCache");
cache.put("k", "v", new CreatedExpiryPolicy(new Duration(TimeUnit.MILLISECONDS, 5000)));
cache.setExpiryPolicy("k", new CreatedExpiryPolicy(new Duration(TimeUnit.MILLISECONDS, 6000)));
```
and check that entry "k" is never removed from the cache. If the `cache.setExpiryPolicy()` is not called then entry expires in 5 seconds.

comment.body:
Investigation of this issue and testing has determined that the functionality in the code adheres to the contract of the `ICache`  interface for method `setExpiryPolicy`.

See note on JavaDoc :

    * Note: New time-to-live duration is calculated using newly added entry policy's getExpiryForUpdate method
     * immediately after this operation succeeds.

The result is that the `CacheRecord:expiryTime` will get set to a value determined with the use of the `expiryForUpdate` value provided in the expiry policy.  `CreatedExpiryPolicy` returns a `null` for `expiryForUpdate`, leading to a `-1` expiry on the record - which means we will never expire the record. 

With the test case provided you have two options to achieve the result you expected: 

(1) invoke `setExpiryPolicy` for the cache entry with a policy such as `HazelcastExpiryPolicy` which accepts `createDurationAmount`, `accessDurationAmount`, `updateDurationAmount`-> supply updateDurationAmount as 6000 ms.  
(2) re-invoke the original `put` with the new `CreatedExpiryPolicy`. 

Closing with this context - thanks for raising this issue!
most changes are expected header changes, but on this file and on all other tests that have changed... is that an expected change?

pull_request.title: Regenerate client-protocol classes following unused import suppression
pull_request.body:
The generated client-protocol classes are full of unused imports - in https://github.com/hazelcast/hazelcast-client-protocol/issues/482 the generator was changed to add a suppression to these generated classes.

This PR is to import these regenerated classes.

issue.title: Fix setExpiryPolicy for ICache

labels.name: Source: Internal
labels.description: PR or issue was opened by an employee

issue.body:
Issue #25547 found that it is possible to update the expiry policy for a ICache entry and it would never get removed in-line with the provided policy. The issue appears to be that the update to the records policy accessed the expiry-for-update time (which is null) rather than creation time, which meant the record is updated with the value `-1` for expiry time. 

Added unit tests to cover the reported failure case. 

Fixes #25547 

Checklist:
- [X] Labels (`Team:`, `Type:`, `Source:`, `Module:`) and Milestone set
- [X] Add `Add to Release Notes` label if changes should be mentioned in release notes or `Not Release Notes content` if changes are not relevant for release notes
- [X] Request reviewers if possible

comment.body: @JackPGreen @JamesHazelcast FYI closing this as on closer inspection I have determined that this functionality is in-line with the API contract. Will post more details on the original ticket.

pull_request.title: Add data connection to remote map source [HZ-3470]
pull_request.body:
Jira : https://hazelcast.atlassian.net/browse/HZ-3479

The Jira issue mentions that data connection should be added to both source and sinks. I have decided to implement it in two PRs.

This PR adds HZ Data connection to remote map source. 

Summary of Changes :

- The tests in Sources related to remote map are moved into a new Test. New tests are added for data connection
- A parameter object has been defined to avoid passing too many parameters down from Sources
- The DataConnectionBase is AutoCloseable. This make it  usable from try with resources 


Checklist:
- [x] Labels (`Team:`, `Type:`, `Source:`, `Module:`) and Milestone set
- [x] Label `Add to Release Notes` or `Not Release Notes content` set
- [x] Request reviewers if possible

repo.name: hazelcast
repo.description: Open-source distributed computation and storage platform

repo.name: hazelcast
repo.description: Hazelcast is a unified real-time data platform combining stream processing with a fast data store, allowing customers to act instantly on data-in-motion for real-time insights.

comment.body:
> I have other problem with DataConnections - we create them, no clients, but DC is alive. We connect with them, release and the release kills DC

Check `DataConnectionBase.refCounter` - it is initially 1. The refCounter may reach 0 only when the DC is replaced with new version or deleted.

comment.body:
> *

Note that unlike the {@link java.io.Closeable#close close} > * method of {@link java.io.Closeable}, this {@code close} method > * is not required to be idempotent. In other words, > * calling this {@code close} method more than once may have some > * visible side effect, unlike {@code Closeable.close} which is > * required to have no effect if called more than once. From AutoCloseable#close JavaDoc. That means close does not have to be idempotent, can be called more than once. I have other problem with DataConnections - we create them, no clients, but DC is alive. We connect with them, release and the release kills DC - we can't use it anymore. Why, if the state is exactly the same as right after creation?

pull_request.title: Fix setExpiryPolicy for ICache
pull_request.body:
Issue #25547 found that it is possible to update the expiry policy for a ICache entry and it would never get removed in-line with the provided policy. The issue appears to be that the update to the records policy accessed the expiry-for-update time (which is null) rather than creation time, which meant the record is updated with the value `-1` for expiry time. 

Added unit tests to cover the reported failure case. 

Fixes #25547 

Checklist:
- [X] Labels (`Team:`, `Type:`, `Source:`, `Module:`) and Milestone set
- [X] Add `Add to Release Notes` label if changes should be mentioned in release notes or `Not Release Notes content` if changes are not relevant for release notes
- [X] Request reviewers if possible

issue.title: Add ANALYZE statement syntax [HZ-2863]
issue.body:
Adds the SQL language extension/scaffolding for ANALYZE statement.

Allows to run an interactive query as a normal job. In this stage OPTIONS are not yet validated or used. ANALYZE also does not yet work with IMap*Plans.

issue.title: Add ANALYZE statement syntax [HZ-2863]
issue.body:
Adds the SQL language extension/scaffolding for ANALYZE statement.

Allows to run an interactive query as a normal job. In this stage OPTIONS are not yet validated or used. ANALYZE also does not yet work with IMap*Plans.

comment.body:
> Nit-pick but you're using the jupiter extension `Assertions` in a legacy JUnit test class - I'd prefer to see `Assert` used here

Good spot - I don't think you can mix&match like that.

pull_request.title: Fix setExpiryPolicy for ICache
pull_request.body:
Issue #25547 found that it is possible to update the expiry policy for a ICache entry and it would never get removed in-line with the provided policy. The issue appears to be that the update to the records policy accessed the expiry-for-update time (which is null) rather than creation time, which meant the record is updated with the value `-1` for expiry time. 

Added unit tests to cover the reported failure case. 

Fixes #25547

- [X] Add `Add to Release Notes` label if changes should be mentioned in release notes or `Not Release Notes content` if changes are not relevant for release notes

issue.title: Support join for stream + jdbc [HZ-2377]
issue.body:
This PR covers 

1. Stream to Batch join
```
SELECT n.id, n.name, n.ssn , t.v FROM 
TABLE(GENERATE_STREAM(2)) t 
JOIN " + tableName + " n ON t.v = n.id 

SELECT n.id, n.name, n.ssn , t.v FROM 
TABLE(GENERATE_STREAM(2)) t 
LEFT OUTER JOIN " + tableName + " n ON t.v = n.id 
```
For these SQLS the index for JDBC is not provided by the infrastructure. So right side JDBC performs full scan

2. Batch to Batch join
```
SELECT t1.id, t2.name FROM tableName t1 
JOIN otherTableName  t2
ON t1.id = t2.id

SELECT t1.id, t2.name FROM tableName t1 
LEFT OUTER JOIN otherTableName  t2
ON t1.id = t2.id
```
For these SQLS the index for JDBC are provided by the infrastructure. So right side JDBC performs index scan

Checklist:
- [x] Labels (`Team:`, `Type:`, `Source:`, `Module:`) and Milestone set
- [x] Label `Add to Release Notes` or `Not Release Notes content` set
- [x] Request reviewers if possible

issue.title: Add ANALYZE statement syntax [HZ-2863]
issue.body:
Adds the SQL language extension/scaffolding for ANALYZE statement.

Allows to run an interactive query as a normal job. In this stage OPTIONS are not yet validated or used. ANALYZE also does not yet work with IMap*Plans.

issue.title: Add ANALYZE statement syntax [HZ-2863]
issue.body:
Adds the SQL language extension/scaffolding for ANALYZE statement.

Allows to run an interactive query as a normal job. In this stage OPTIONS are not yet validated or used. ANALYZE also does not yet work with IMap*Plans.
